q2.description: As we said before, PDAs have 2 different types of language acceptance. In this module we will cver the second type of acceptance.
q2.question: What was the first one?

q3.description: $\textbf{Definition:}$ Let NPDA $M = (Q, \Sigma, \Gamma, \delta, q_0, z, \emptyset)$ accepts $L(M)$ by empty stack, $L(M) = \{w \in \Sigma^* | (q_0, w, z) \stackrel{*}{\vdash} (p, \lambda, \lambda)\}$
q3.question: Look carefully at the definition of $M$. What is missing?

q4.description: $\textbf{Definition:}$ Let NPDA $M = (Q, \Sigma, \Gamma, \delta, q_0, z, \emptyset)$ accepts $L(M)$ by empty stack, $L(M) = \{w \in \Sigma^* | (q_0, w, z) \stackrel{*}{\vdash} (p, \lambda, \lambda)\}$
q4.question: By reading $(q_0, w, z) \stackrel{*}{\vdash} (p, \lambda, \lambda)\}$. What does it mean that $q_0$ changed to $p$?
q4.answer: The machine moved from start stat to another state $q$
choices: The machine moved from start stat to another state $q$
The string is consumed by machine
The stack content is changed based on the transitions

q5.description: $\textbf{Definition:}$ Let NPDA $M = (Q, \Sigma, \Gamma, \delta, q_0, z, \emptyset)$ accepts $L(M)$ by empty stack, $L(M) = \{w \in \Sigma^* | (q_0, w, z) \stackrel{*}{\vdash} (p, \lambda, \lambda)\}$
q5.question: By reading $(q_0, w, z) \stackrel{*}{\vdash} (p, \lambda, \lambda)\}$. Is $p$ a final state?
q5.answer: No, we do not have a final state in this type of acceptance
choices: No, we do not have a final state in this type of acceptance

q6.description: $\textbf{Definition:}$ Let NPDA $M = (Q, \Sigma, \Gamma, \delta, q_0, z, \emptyset)$ accepts $L(M)$ by empty stack, $L(M) = \{w \in \Sigma^* | (q_0, w, z) \stackrel{*}{\vdash} (p, \lambda, \lambda)\}$
q6.question: By reading $(q_0, w, z) \stackrel{*}{\vdash} (p, \lambda, \lambda)\}$. What does it mean that $w$ changed to $\lambda$?
q6.answer: The string is consumed by machine
choices: The machine moved from start stat to another state $q$
The string is consumed by machine
The stack content is changed based on the transitions

q7.description: $\textbf{Definition:}$ Let NPDA $M = (Q, \Sigma, \Gamma, \delta, q_0, z, \emptyset)$ accepts $L(M)$ by empty stack, $L(M) = \{w \in \Sigma^* | (q_0, w, z) \stackrel{*}{\vdash} (p, \lambda, \lambda)\}$
q7.question: By reading $(q_0, w, z) \stackrel{*}{\vdash} (p, \lambda, \lambda)\}$. What does it mean that $z$ changed to $\lambda$?
choices: The machine moved from start stat to another state $q$
The string is consumed by machine

q8.question: What is the language represented by the PDA?

q9.description:
$\textbf{Example}$ $L = \{a^nb^mc^{n+m} | n,m > 0\}, \Sigma = \{a, b, c\}, \Gamma =\{0, z\}$
Let us see the trace for the string $aabccc$
q9.question: Is string $aabccc$ in the language?

q23.answer: Move to $q_4$ and pop $Z$ from the stack
choices: Move to $q_4$ and pop $Z$ from the stack

q24.description:
$\textbf{Example}$ $L = \{a^nb^mc^{n+m} | n,m > 0\}, \Sigma = \{a, b, c\}, \Gamma =\{0, z\}$
Let us see the trace for the string $aabccc$
q24.question: Will the string be accepted?
q24.answer: Yes, the machine ended with empty stack
choices: Yes, the machine ended with empty stack
No, the machine end in a non-final state

q25.description:
$\textbf{Example}$ $L = \{a^nb^mc^{n+m} | n,m > 0\}, \Sigma = \{a, b, c\}, \Gamma =\{0, z\}$
Let us see the trace for the string $aabc$
q25.question: What about the string $aabc$, will it be accepted?
q25.answer: No, it is not in the language
choices: No, it is not in the language
